title: A Letter To Riot on LCS and Competitive rulings
body:
Dear Riot,

     I have been a big esports fan from the end of season 3, I have always enjoyed watching teams play. seeing pros make plays I didn't know was possible watching as the champions move around the rift like a game of chess between two brilliant teams. It was always fun and engaging. but recently some events have occurred behind the scenes that have completely ruined this aspect of League of Legends for me. 

   I am Very displeased with the way you have been handling your LCS competitive rulings lately. There are massive inconsistencies that show Bias towards certain teams and has completely ruined the LCS for me. More specifically your ruling on REN/TDK and G2/FNC are so different that it disgusts me. I dont understand how you can completely screw 1 set of teams then turn around and turn a blind eye on another. 

> Rules and context copy/pasted out of your public articles concerning these punishments

http://www.lolesports.com/en_US/articles/competitive-ruling-renegades-and-tdk
3.1 Team Ownership Restriction

...Any buyback provision, _**right of first purchase**_, or similar interest in a team shall be treated as a controlling interest in such team for the purposes of enforcing ownership restrictions…

...any present or **_future right to ownership is considered a firm ownership stake _**regardless of the date of effect...

http://www.lolesports.com/en_US/articles/competitive-ruling-g2-esports-and-fnatic

...which essentially means that Hilgers gets**_ first rights on aforementioned equity_** if Sannpa defaults.

...it does not create a future state wherein he would be guaranteed control of Fnatic...
> 

        By Hilgers making his loan so that he gets First rights on the equity in Sannapa which, is the parent company of Fnatic, which means they own a controlling interest in the team, if they default does that not create a possible future where he would be guaranteed partial ownership in Fnatic. How is this any different than Monte promising (There is NOTHING in writing supplied to the viewers and fans proving this) Badawi a stake in Renegades. therefore creating a POSSIBLE future where he would be guaranteed partial ownership, as we don't know if they ever created a legally binding contract concerning this matter. According to riot any such condition will be " treated as a controlling interest in such team for the purposes of enforcing ownership restrictions… " so the two instances should have been treated similarly.

    I am sorry to say that I will most likely not be watching worlds this year and possibly LCS ever again. As nothing you could do now could ever reconcile the damage done to renegades as a team, not just the league team. your lack of consistency when you decide to dole out punishments has left a poor impression on me as Riot as a company and League of Legends as an esports platform. I can only urge you to be more consistent and transparent in your rulings for the future 

With Many Regrets,
A past LCS Fan{{champion:32}}

It's not the same offense. It's a much less egregious offence whose only similarity is 'money is involved'. In one case it was the actual owner, in the other case it was a minority shareholder. That's a BIG difference.

Riot banned Montecristo because they claimed (they have yet to provide any evidence whatsoever that this happened) that he promised a previously banned individual a future stake in his company. This is a possible future share of ownership entirely dependent on Monte agreeing to give up a share, and Riot secondly agreeing to Badawi being allowed ownership. Since Riot would have to agree to Badawi being an owner, it's pretty ridiculous for Monte to be banned for supposedly doing something which is not possible for him to do. Riot MUST approve all owners before they are allowed. So it is possible Monte agreed that Badawi could be given a share of Renegades (we have no proof of this) but even if this had occurred, it would have been a pointless agreement since Riot would have to approve Badawi themselves if or when this happened. 

G2 got in trouble because their owner had a possible scenario where he could own and/or exert influence on fnatic, which is not allowed, owning two teams is not allowed and everyone knows this. In this scenario there is actual evidence of wrongdoing. 

The cases are the same because they both got in trouble for promising or being promised ownership that they were not supposed to have or give. The cases are different because one has evidence and one does not. The cases are different because one owner lost literally nothing, and the other owner lost his entire eSports business ultimately.

There are a few very massive differences. One being the fact that in one case it was ACTUALLY the owner committing the error and in the other it was a MINORITY HOLDER. In the one case, it was a controlling interest that is being discussed, in the other it's a minor financial interest. In the one case, it was direct involvement of the team itself, in the other it was a stage removed(financial interest in the parent company as opposed to direct controlling interest in the team).

Ren/TDK the accusation was that Monte was planning to give Badawi a controlling interest in the team.

FNC/G2 the accusation is basically that Fnatic's parent company and G2 both took out a loan from the same bank.

I have no reason to believe Riot is lying to us or that they don't have the evidence. And I understand that it is not always legally permissible to provide incriminating information about an individual in a public place, so I can appreciate why they cannot provide the evidence.

Unlike a lot of people around here, I simply don't have any irrational feelings - positive or negative - towards Riot, so I'm able to think of the situation from a logical perspective as opposed to immediately jumping to the 'RIOT IS THE DEVIL' cries that most of these posts basically amount to.



That being said, I fully expect you to not believe a word I said and for this to be a waste of my time because of your final statement.

Conditions of the loan stated that if fnatic defaulted on the loan then Hilger could obtain a percentage of ownership in fnatic as compensation, thus becoming an owner with stake in multiple teams. 

Not "took out a loan from the same bank"

Those arguments aren't mutually exclusive. If you default on a loan, the person who lends to you gets something in return. In businesses, that's usually a share of ownership.

LMFAO "LEAST DESIRABLE RESULT"

If an experienced businessman like Jens Hilger gives a loan _out of his own pocket_ to a company _he knows is struggling financially_, he's most likely betting that they're going to default on the loan. 

Combine this with the fact he actively hid the evidence until Richard Lewis dug it up, at which point it's foolish to try beating around the bush.

Maybe you think you're smart and understand legal nuances, but you sure as hell don't understand business dealings. Jens Hilger _did not_ give this loan out of the goodness of his heart. Using loan defaults to gain indirect control is one of the oldest business tricks in the book.

And if you remember from the Ren/TDK case, I paraphrase: any possibility of future ownership is considered a firm ownership stake, and is therefore in direct violation of league rules.

It's not hard to figure out.. Riot went apeshit on one case without evidence for a shit load of charges that don't seem backed up by much. Then they did nothing on the case WITH evidence saying "Oh it was just an accident I'm sure G2 didn't MEAN to buy a potential share of FNC, it was just a unexpected byproduct of another deal!!!"

If echo fox did that with NRG, they would be banned.

It is really a stretch to say that Hilgers will end up owning stake in both teams.

It is a weird situation but it is close to a situation where both teams got a loan from the same bank. It would be odd to punish them in this situation.

The Renegades situation is different though. They kicked them out for a bunch of different nitpicky stuff but what I read out of that is that they didn't like Monte so they came up with every single thing he did wrong and put it on one document. Even if there isn't enough to actually ban his team from their game, there was enough there that it would be hard to dispute (legally). Basically they just looked for an excuse they could use to wash their hands of him.

That doesn't mean that they should nitpick and boot every organization in the future just because they shouldn't have done what they did with Renegades.
I am not saying i want Fnatic and G2 banned. I do want teams to be punished eqaully though

I agree that Renegades shouldn't have been banned but keeping that as the standard moving forward would be really bad for the scene.

I can't think of a fair way to resolve that except to have never made the mistake in the first place.

it would be nice if riot released either their evidence or an apology. I think it would also be nice if they had a third party do the investigations/act as a means for ban appeals. those are the only ways they could really rectify.

They also need to increase the prizepool for worlds and or pay players more money throughout the season. These kids are often giving up on school etc to make everyone a lot of money. Perhaps some sort of lifetime medical or retirement? PROGRESS Rito, plz.

Riot's better on that than any other esports by far. The prize pool at TI looks nice, but if you're not Top 6, you're getting less than half a million dollars, down to a hundred thousand, which isn't a whole lot to run a whole esports team and pay all the players top dollar. And that's just for the 16 teams that made it to TI, it's even worse for everyone else. League players actually get a salary, and while a larger prize pool would be nicer (I think Riot could do the TI thing where they sell skins that go towards the prize pool), it's definitely the better option.

You're right that League is definitely doing well in terms of player play. It's actually one of the only things we match CSGO and DOTA players with.  But that has nothing to do with Riot. Riot do pay part of a players salary via a stipend, but that stipend is like 2000$ max. Players typically cost in 80-150 thousand. Rising player costs and no money inflow is probably why teams like UOL are straight up not making money and have stated that they are not spending anymore extra money on the scene.

An increased Prize pool would be nice but i dont think it would solve the teams current financial issues. Alot of that revolves around Venture capitalists putting alot of money into building new teams which skyrockets the prices of players. The teams that have been around for a while such as (we will use Fnatic b/c they were in need of a loan here) are struggling to stay out of the red... Not bad for players, but considering how difficult it is to find income besides sponsors, not sustainable.

Not necessarily in that order, I think teams would prefer the guaranteed money to make a winning team rather than need to win to make a winning team... But yes, progress is what we need and supposedly it's what we'll get.
